user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_ctz_traverse:
```c
static int lfs_ctz_traverse(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache,
        lfs_block_t head, lfs_size_t size,
        int (*cb)(void*, lfs_block_t), void *data) {
    if (size == 0) {
        return 0;
    }

    lfs_off_t index = lfs_ctz_index(lfs, &(lfs_off_t){size-1});

    while (true) {
        int err = cb(data, head);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (index == 0) {
            return 0;
        }

        lfs_block_t heads[2];
        int count = 2 - (index & 1);
        err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
                pcache, rcache, count*sizeof(head),
                head, 0, &heads, count*sizeof(head));
        heads[0] = lfs_fromle32(heads[0]);
        heads[1] = lfs_fromle32(heads[1]);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        for (int i = 0; i < count-1; i++) {
            err = cb(data, heads[i]);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }
        }

        head = heads[count-1];
        index -= count;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_ctz_traverse:
typedef uint32_t lfs_block_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_size_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_off_t
...
typedef struct lfs_cache {
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_size_t size;
    uint8_t *buffer;
} lfs_cache_t
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the assignment to the parameter 'head' modifies a function parameter variable; this directly violates Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified). Other statements either modify local variables (e.g. index, heads[], err), call functions with parameters (e.g. cb(data, head), lfs_bd_read(...)), or modify objects via pointer parameters (none in this function body), which is permitted by the rule. No pointer parameter itself (lfs, pcache, rcache, cb, data) is reassigned in the function, and no other parameter variables (size, cb, data, lfs, pcache, rcache) are assigned to. Therefore no other fragments need investigation under Rule 17.8.
